page.title: List of Pakistan Air Force Squadrons

revisions.rev:
{{unreliable sources|date=November 2011}} {{Pakistan Air Force}} {{main|Pakistan Air Force}} '''Squadrons''' are the most basic flying unit of the '''[[Pakistan Air Force]]''' ('''PAF'''). [[Combat aircraft]] squadrons contain around 20 aircraft. Squadron titles incorporate a squadron number and each squadron also has a nickname associated with it. PAF squadrons are organised into [[Wing (military aviation unit)|wings]] which contain multiple squadrons. ==Active squadrons== {{Standard table|0}} ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Squadron ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Name ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Operational ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Aircraft ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Role ! style="text-align: left; background: lavender;"|Notes |-valign="top" |style="width:90px"| No. 1 Sqn | ''Rahbars'' | '''1975'''

MS | Formed as part of No. 31 Bomber Wing on 11 May 1960, equipped with the [[B-57 Canberra]] and lead by Squadron Leader Muhammad Iqbal. Disbanded and resources amalgamated with No. 7 Squadron after the 1965 Indo-Pak War due to B-57 spare parts supply being stopped by United States. Re-activated with [[Dassault Mirage 5]] in 1982.{{cite web|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/may99/b-57.htm|title=B-57 THE INTREPID BOMBER OF PAF|last=Gp Capt SULTAN M HALI|publisher=Defence Journal|accessdate=11 May 2011}} |-valign="top" | [[No. 9 Squadron Griffins|No. 9 Sqn]] | [[No. 9 Squadron Griffins|''Griffins'']] | '''1943'''

[[F-16|F-16 A/B]] |




TA
OCU
MR | Second unit to be equipped with the [[F-16]]. Credited with 3 kills: two [[Su-22]] on 17 May 1986 by Squadron Leader Mohammed Yousaf and an [[An-26]] on 30 March 1987 by Squadron Leader Sikander Hayat. Equipped with the [[ATLIS II]] targeting pod in 1987 for ground attack role.{{cite web|url=http://www.f-16.net/units_article292.html|title=9 sqn "Griffins" (PAF)|publisher=www.f-16.net|accessdate=11 April 2010}} Commanded by Wg. Cmd. Aamir Masood in 2006, who is now flying [[Sukhoi Su-30MKK]] with the [[People's Liberation Army Navy|Chinese Navy (PLAN)]].{{cite web|url=http://www.f-16.net/pilots-profile2105.html|title=Viper Driver Flying Hours - Wg.Cmd. Aamir Masood |publisher=www.f-16.net|accessdate=11 April 2010}} |-valign="top" - style="background:#efefef; color:black" | No. 10 Sqn | | '''1959'''

MRTT | Established as the No. 10 Multi-Role Tanker Transport (MRTT) Squadron with delivery of the PAF's first [[Il-78]] in December 2009 and operating from [[PAF Base Chaklala]].{{cite journal|last=Warnes|first=Alan|date=July 2010|title=On The Edge|journal=Air Forces Monthly|publisher=Key Publishing Limited|location=United Kingdom|issue=July 2010|page=Page 56|quote=Last year saw the delivery of the first Il-78 Midas air-to-air refueller and also the first Russian aircraft into the inventory - hence the R in front of the serial. The newly established 10 Multi Role Tanker Transport Sqn at Chaklala operates the aircraft, which will be joined by a second example.|url=http://www.airforcesmonthly.com/view_issue.asp?ID=744|accessdate=9 July 2010}} |-valign="top" | [[No. 11 Squadron Arrows|No. 11 Sqn]] | [[No. 11 Squadron Arrows|''Arrows'']] | '''1949'''

[[JF-17 Thunder]] | TA


TA
MR | Became the Fighter Leaders School in 1971. First squadron to fly A-5C, first A-5s landing at PAF Base Rafiqui on 12 February 1983. Converted pilots of No. 7 and No. 26 Squadrons to fly the A-5. Flew against the F-16 extensively during dissimilar aircraft combat training (DACT) in 1985.http://www.pakdef.info/pakmilitary/airforce/squadrons/sqdr16.html Also flew 1v1 DACT missions against the F-7P in 1988. In 1990, Wing Commander Zafar took part in an evaluation of the [[Nanchang A-5|Nanchang A-5M]] and [[Nanchang A-5|A-5F]].http://www.pakdef.info/pakmilitary/airforce/squadrons/no16_2.html Officially converted to the [[JF-17 Thunder]] on 11 April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.key.aero/view_news.asp?ID=3076&thisSection=military|accessdate=13 April 2011}} |-valign="top" | No. 17 Sqn | ''Tigers'' | '''1957'''

[[K-8 Karakorum]] | | The Sherdils Squadron is the aerobatics display team of the Pakistan Air Force Academy, based at PAF Risalpur. The team flew the [[T-37 Tweet]] until circa 2010, when they switched to the [[K-8 Karakorum]], and is composed of instructors of the Basic Flying Training (BFT) Wing. |-valign="top" - style="background:#efefef; color:black" | No. 81 Sqn | ''Kangaroos'' | | Alouette 3 | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Peshawar]].http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" | No. 82 Sqn | | | Alouette 3 | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Mushaf]].http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" - style="background:#efefef; color:black" | No. 83 Sqn | ''Dolphins'' | | Alouette 3, Mi-171Sh | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Masroor]].http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" | No. 85 Sqn | | | Alouette 3 | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Samungli]].http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" - style="background:#efefef; color:black" | No. 86 Sqn | ''Ababeel'' | | Alouette 3 | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Mianwali]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pakdef.info/pakmilitary/airforce/orbat/orbat2009.html|accessdate=9 June 2011}} http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" | No. 87 Sqn | | | Alouette 3 | SAR | Stationed at [[PAF Base Minhas]].http://www.scramble.nl/mil/3/pakaf/orbat.htm |-valign="top" |CCS |''Skybolts'' | |

[[Sikorsky H-19|Sikorsky H-19D]] |

MR
T

MR
SAR | Formed on 15 August 1959 with four Bristol Freighters and four Grumman SA-16 Albatross amphibious aircraft, two of which were transferred from No. 12 squadron. Strength reduced to two SA-16 and two Sikorsky H-19D on 8 July 1960. SA-16 aircraft taken out of service on 19 August 1968, later followed by the H-19D. Squadron "number-plated" in March 1969.{{cite web|url=http://www.pakdef.info/pakmilitary/airforce/squadrons/no4_2.html|title=No. 4 Squadron|publisher=Pakistan Military Consortium (PakDef.info)|accessdate=26 March 2010}} |-valign="top" | JF-17 TEF | 2007â2010 | [[JF-17]] | T&E | Established on 20 February 2007 as JF-17 Test and Evaluation Flight, commanded by Wg Cdr Ahsan Rafiq and stationed at [[PAF Base Minhas]], Kamra. Transformed into No. 26 ''Black Spiders'' Squadron on 18 February 2010 when No. 26 officially converted from the [[Nanchang A-5|Nanchang A-5C]] to the [[JF-17]].{{cite journal|last=Warnes|first=Alan|date=July 2011|title=JF-17 - Thunder from the East|journal=Air Forces Monthly|publisher=Key Publishing|issue=#280|pages=47â70}} {{Close table}} '''Key:''' SAR = Search and Rescue MR = Maritime Reconnaissance == References == ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== * [http://www.pakdef.info/pakmilitary/airforce/squadrons/index.html Pakistan Military Consortium] * [http://paffalcons.com/squadrons/index.php Pakistan Air Force - Second to None] {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Pakistan Air Force Aircraft Squadrons}} [[Category:Pakistan Air Force]] [[Category:Lists of military units and formations]] [[Category:Pakistan Air Force Squadrons]]
